Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 05:04PM Vicks1960 wrote: Yippie  one dreaded step out of the way!!!!!  Now you can breath a few deep breaths!!!! At our hospital here (small town small hospital but has digital imaging)  The 'pictures' are sent directly to a radiologist in the city.  They have a basket of small containers of deodorant for you to to help yourself to after the mammogram is completed.  Nice touch. We are about 75 miles from Lincoln, NE where they have larger excellent  hospitals and medical care and some of the physicians hold visits here and our local drs. freely suggest using them if needed. leelee Keep hanging in there!!!!  As you are learning, we have a GREAT SUPPORT SYSTEM here for each other,... Vickie

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 06:55PM Vicks1960 wrote: I finished Contura Balloon brachytherapy radiation Nov. 18, 2011.  I still have sensitivity, and sometimes some sharp pains.  The sharp pains, I believe are the nerves repairing themselves.  I too have follow up diagnostic mammo, see M/O  and R/O in mid April. Have been on Letrozole (Femara) since Nov. 21. Vickie

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 04:31PM Vicks1960 wrote: LeeLee: So glad you found us.....We are each on this journey, perhaps different roads but headed to the same destination BEAT THIS BC!!   Most of us have gone through the anxiety of waiting (seems like forever) for the results to be given to us, but have made it.....Just reading the different posts here, can give a person courage, and making your own post to vent can be a big help mentally/emotionally. You can take pride from the book your daughter made for you.  She must be a really special girl,,  Sounds like she is a strong girl (an inherited trait, maybe?).  Keep your chin up and hopefully take comfort in the fact there are many of us pulling, and praying for you..... Vickie

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2012 08:22PM Vicks1960 wrote: Hi All While waiting for the Ocono type test results to get back, my MO had me get a PET scan. (I was 68 at the time).  That showed no evidence of disease elsewhere.  Scan went from top of skull to mid thighs.   Since my Onco score is at the lower end of the scale, he said he saw no reason for me to go through chemo.  I did have Brachytherapy radiation, and have been on Letrozole since mid November last year.   I am headed for my 2nd semi-annual checkup (mammo and appointments with both RO and MO) next month.  Checkup in April was NED!!!!!! I am hoping for same result this time..

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 12:12AM Vicks1960 wrote: LWA I finished the Contura Balloon Brachytherapy a month ago.  So far so good.  There was a rebutal published a few days after the first article that came out of the SanAntonio.  My RO was involved in the original study/development of the Brachytherapy.   I am still healing from all the mutilations the breast had with 3 surgeries, 10 rad treatments, then a drain.  It was very uncomfortable for a while but is much better now. Good luck, I will include you in my prayers that you will be guided in the treatment that is appropriate for you..... Vickie

Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2012 09:41AM Vicks1960 wrote: Bellinda, I also developed a huge hematoma a few days after surgery, and it was VERY UNCOMFORTABLE and HUGE! My BS and his office gal told my husband they had never seen one so large.  Any way he performed surgery right away to excise the hematoma and removed 1000cc of fluids.  It took a long time for the breast to start looking somewhat normal.  I am sure that surgery 10 days later to insert the Contura Balloon for the Brachytherapy rad.treatments also added some of the color. Also, a few days after the rads. they had to put in a drain for about a week.  This was all last Oct/Nov.  The underside of the breast still looks a bit tanned, but everything is doing well.... I jokingly said to my surgeon, that I was as perky as an 18 year old.  He chuckled and told me "no, just half an 18".   It will get easier.... Vickie

Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2012 03:30PM Vicks1960 wrote: Carey In my case my tumor was E+P+Her-.  It was stage 1 but a grade 3 (very agressive grade).  The MO had an Oncotype test done on it, and because of my age (69) clean nodes, and the test results, he said he saw no benefit in me having Chemo.  I did have the  Contura Balloon radiation (inside area where tumor had been).   I woud ask her surgeon about the swiming aspect......  I sympathize with your mom over the back surgery.  I had 1 in 1971, 1 in 1981 and 2 in 1983.  Still have residual pain (sciatic) and neuropathy in feet, have learned to live with it... I hope you all have a nice 'vacation', and that mom will  really enjoy the extra family time. Vickie
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2012 08:02PM - edited Aug 17, 2012 08:03PM by Vicks1960 Good evening gals! About 10 days ago I found a lump in the same breast that I had the partial mastectomy done on last October...Waited a few days, because I didn't want to 'cry wolf'... Anyway a couple of days ago, I called my PCP and he had me come in the next day (yesterday).  He found the lump w/o me having to tell him where it is... He immediately had his nurse contact our local hospital for a diagnostic mammogram, done this morning.  Tech sent it immediately to the radiologist in Lincoln.  Rad. said she could not see anything there, but ordered an ultrasound to be done, because sometimes a US will detect something the Mammo doesn't. Anyway, to shorten the story, the US tech found a pretty good sized seroma in the breast, and thinks that possibly it might be putting pressure on the tissues causing it to feel like a lump.  However, I am waiting for the report from the radiologist.  I am wondering, why a seroma would show up now (10 months since surgery)?  Have any of you had this experience? Would be interested in hearing your experiences, did they leave it alone to be re-absorbed in your system, did they aspirate it or put a drain in....how was it treated.. Vickie

GOOD LUCK Vickie

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2012 11:01AM Vicks1960 wrote: Auntienance Thanks for your input.....I really appreciate you gals sharing your experiences with me.  It gives me more to go on when I hear from the Drs. next week, and maybe have more intelligent questions for them....  I believe that this seroma is the reason I have been having discomfort in that breast for quite a while, yet when I would comment to the Dr's about it, "I don't know what could be causing it" (this might be a bit of a paraphrase) would be the reply....(oh, it was discomfort not real pain). Just curious, did you have brachytherapy radiation or full external rad?  I have read that the brachytherapy can sometimes cause some uv burning, which leads to the seroma formation.......? don't know,. Again, THANKS. Vickie

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2012 11:51AM Vicks1960 wrote: Belinda, I am another person who can add my name to the list of 'sharp pains in the breast' club.  My RO said is is because of the damaged nerves repairing themselves.  I am 9 months post surgical (8 mo post rad) and on the rare occasion I still get a stab. My left breast has shrunk quite a bit, more than 1 cup smaller than my right one.  I tell my husband & daughter, that I am "lop sided hanna'.  That is by far better than no breast and being CANCER FREE!!!!!!!! Have been VERY PLEASED with the care i have received from my different physicians!!! Vickie
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 05:20PM Vicks1960 wrote: Had phone call from my PCP today.  He says no signs of malignancy and he suggests just monitoring the area with the lump and if it continues to grow we will remove it. He also agreed that the seroma could be pushing the tissue to the side, making the lump.  Time will tell. I am waiting to see what the RO and MO in Lincoln have to say after they receive the reports.... I feel so fortunate to have Doctors that listen to me when I say I think somthing is wrong!!!!!!!. Vickie

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2011 07:17PM Vicks1960 wrote: AnneWisc. I just started the brachytherapy rads today.  Had surgery last Thurs. to implant the balloon, saw the RO Friday to be sure it was placed correctly.  Had first treatment this a.m. with 2nd treatment about 3:00 this p.m.  So far no problem other that carry over from the MX, hematoma.   Meet with the MO tomorrow.  Think he probably will give me the results of the OconoT test they have done on the tumor, and start me on the hormone blocking pills. Understand those will be needed for 5 years.  Will know more tomorrow afternoon (I hope) Good luck with your treatments... we will have to keep in touch...

Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2012 03:34PM Vicks1960 wrote: Jen, SOOO SORRY for the 'news' you received this am.  only good thing is now you know more of what you have to deal with..... For me, knowing what is happening, makes it easier to handle.  I had my modified mastectomy last Oct. had the Brachytherapy in November.  Go back for diagnostic mammo, see the MO and the RO mid April.  And have some concern about it, but know that initial diagnosis is like being slugged in the gut, it completely consumes your thinking for some time. Please keep us posted, I know you will find lots of 'help' dealing with the rotten BC, from the gals who post here.  I certainly have.   Vickie
